They've gotten their definition of socialism all wrong.

Socialism is the transition from a free market economy into communism (a society where no one has any self interest).
As described by Marx in "Critique Of the Gotha Program":
"What we have to deal with here is a communist society, not as it has developed on its own foundations, but, on the contrary, just as it emerges from capitalist society; which is thus in every respect, economically, morally, and intellectually, still stamped with the birthmarks of the old society from whose womb it emerges. Accordingly, the individual producer receives back from society – after the deductions have been made – exactly what he gives to it. What he has given to it is his individual quantum of labor. For example, the social working day consists of the sum of the individual hours of work; the individual labor time of the individual producer is the part of the social working day contributed by him, his share in it. He receives a certificate from society that he has furnished such-and-such an amount of labor (after deducting his labor for the common funds); and with this certificate, he draws from the social stock of means of consumption as much as the same amount of labor cost. The same amount of labor which he has given to society in one form, he receives back in another."

Adam Smith’s position as a customs agent is full of irony. In The Wealth of Nations, Smith argued in favor of free trade. He endorsed the elimination of most tariffs and even wrote in sympathy of smuggling. Two years after his publications, in 1778 Smith actively sought a high-level government appointment, possibly to enhance his financial condition. Smith succeeded in his quest and was named Commissioner of Customs in Scotland, despite his previous writings on free trade and the words of his friend Dr. Samuel Johnson, who said that “one of the lowest of all human beings is a Commissioner of Excise” (in Viner 1965, 64). The job was a prestigious position that paid a handsome £600 a year. In a strange paradox, the champion of free trade and laissez-faire spent the last twelve years of his life enforcing Scotland’s mercantilist import laws and cracking down on smugglers. Hey, y’all should read my book, "The End of Prosperity: How Higher Taxes Will Doom the Economy—If We Let It Happen," it the latest bout the theory I've been developing for years, supply side economics. It’s pretty similar to Keynesian in its view that the economy goes through cycles and its needs adjustment to keep aggregate supply and demand around equilibrium, and how the money supply should be kept in check. But supply side economics have much more of a focus on using fiscal policy to adjust taxes. The idea is that if taxes are too high people have no incentive to make money, and businesses have no incentive to produce. I expressed my ideas with the Laffer curve, which shows the relationship between tax revenue vs tax rate.

I notice that you equated people against government supplying the impoverished with assistance with social darwinists. I'd like to make a major clarification.  Most self-proclaimed "Austrian Economists" fall into the political ideology of the bottom right. Many claim the titles of libertarian, ancap, or minarchist. When you look at our political philosophies, it's not about the concept that helping the poor is wrong, it's the concept that taking the property of another through taxation is wrong. You wont likely find more generous or philanthropic people within these groups. Voluntaryism in Action and other charities have sprouted from our political beliefs, showing that people working together without coercion can accomplish more in shorter times than what a state entity can do through decades of extortion and theft through taxation. Though you may disagree on the morality of taxation or government intervention in the economy, or disagree with the plausibility of our economic models, do not equate us to people who see poor people as a blight on society. You dont have to push a false narrative to speak your point of view.

1. Karl Marx
-ruling class vs. working class (capitalism)
-private ownership to collective ownership transition
-abolishment of private property and classless and stateless community.
- communism: all properties are owned by the public but controlled by the government.

2. Adam Smith
- a country's wealth is not determined by gold/silver but its GDP
- specialization and division of labor (Plato)
- capitalist economies are the most beneficial and productive to their societies.

3. Thomas Malthus
- human population will outweigh food production
- did not consider advancement of technology

4. David Ricardo
- theory of comparative advantage: when both focus at what they're best at, and then trade, everyone benefits.

5. Alfred Marshall
- supply and demand and marginal utility

6. John Meynard Keynes
- if a country's investment exceeds its savings, it will cause inflation.
- if a country's savings is higher than its investment, it will cause recession.

Just so we're all clear, "Trickle-down economics" is not another name for Supply-Side Economics, it is a name created by its opponents in order to discredit it. The name itself is a literal strawman, suggesting that Supply-Side proponents believe in the poor getting their money from the rich through possible higher wages. In fact the actual theory says that wealth is most effectively generated through investment, whether in the stock market or in new business. These large investments generally come from those with large amounts of capital, which is why supply-side proponents are in favor of lower corporate taxes, and income taxes, as well as being skeptical of "progressive" tax brackets because they have the effect of punishing people for making money as well as making it harder for high-income people to make meaningful investments.

One of the comments in the video is that economic theory changes over time. We have moved - as H. Daly calls it - from an empty to a full world; and economic theory has not evolved to recognize this change. Natural resources have become the limiting factor (capital and labour being the limiting factor of the past). Neoclassical economics fails to understand this (since it assumes that natural resources can be substituted with human-made capital) and thus cannot help us allocate resources towards the new limiting factor. Furthermore, neoclassical economics - as well as other economic theories of the past - sees the economy as growing into the void rather than as a sub-system of the ecosystem, and thus fail to account for the opportunity cost of economic growth, i.e. ecosystem services (which, again, are the limiting factor today). My comment builds on ecological economics theory (different from environmental economics), which I was hoping the video would have mentioned. Ecological economics is - in my view - the economic theory of the present and future, as it helps us allocate resources better, which is what economic theory should help us with. We've been treated to several economic ideas here but the history of ideas tells us that 99.999999% of all ideas are wrong. All these economic ideas were developed by private individuals and some were adopted and implemented by governments - but never in the exact form as they were conceived. Keynes idea was for governments to kick start a stalled economy by injecting money into the system through infrastructure works that the private sector would not do - like roads, libraries etc but when the private economy showed signs of life through investment projects Keynes said the government should withdraw its involvement and increase taxes to repay the debts created by government investment.

I would say that the second bit - the taxing and repaying hard bit - has never been done because it is a vote loser. Keynes was an English Liberal which is not like an American liberal. He wanted people to be left alone to do as they please and only intervene in the economy when it got stuck. The British Left have no economic heros except Marx, but his ideas frighten normal people so they adopted Keynes because he was English, had great prestige and he said governments should borrow to spend. The Left have a tendency to ignore the bits they don't like and because so few people actually bother to understand economics they have been able to adopt Keynes, the 'state spender' as their economic mascot. The man is probably rolling in his grave at the misappropriation of his ideas but the dead, it seems, have no rights.

I used Keynes as an example of the way that all these ideas have been inappropriately applied and the others in this video could also be contested. It is sometimes useful to consider what system would be in place if all governments everywhere were constitutionally barred from involvement in the economy [what would they do?]. Main outtakes of this lesson
- Economic theories are constantly being proven, disproven and revised.
Incorrect theories
Thomas Malthus - In 1798, he argued that population growth would outpace food production.
Social darwinism - assistance to poor people and welfare are socially immoral. Combined ideas of Darwin & Malthus.

1) Capitalism - free markets and private property
Adam Smith - "The wealth of nations", 1776. A person following their own self-interest could end up serving the common good.
David Ricardo - Theory of comparative advantage: two people or countries can both benefit from trade, even if one of them can produce more of everything (when both focus on what they're best at and then trade, everyone benefits).
John Maynard Keynes - markets and economies don't self-correct quickly because prices and wages take time to adjust. During recessions, the government must get involved by using monetary and fiscal policy to increase output and decrease unemployment.

2) Communism - collective ownership of the means of production in a stateless and classless system
- Communist Manifesto by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels, 1848 - history is explained by the conflict between workers and property owners. Establishment of the Soviet Union in 1922.

3) Classical economics (capitalist ideas)
- Principles of economics by Alfred Marshall, 1890. Government intervention is seen as harmful for the economy.
- Supply and demand. Marginal utility.

4) Socialism - the means of producing and distributing goods is owned collectively or by a centralized government.
- Private property and markets. Government ownership of industry. Significant regulation. Big public programs like universal healthcare. Examples: Norway, Sweden, Spain, France...

5) Austrian school of economics
- Friedrich Hayek and Ludwig von Mises.
- Regulation and government involvement has never produced the results it promised. It's seen as a problem, not a solution.
- Milton Friedman in the US - Chicago School of Economics, proposing privatization, deregulation and school vouchers.

6) Monetarism - Monetarists focus on price stability and argue the money supply should be increased slowly and predictably to allow for steady growth.

7) Supply-side economics or trickle-down economics - Deregulation and cutting taxes, especially corporate taxes.

8) New neoclassical synthesis - Unified theory that includes ideas from classical economics, including monetarism, and Keynesian economics. It is the basis of mainstream economics today. China and Cuba are not communists anymore, they're capitalists. North Korea is communist.

Some notes if anyone needs them!

-Malthus argued that population would increase faster than food production → didn’t address the improvement in technology, now it turns out most famines happen only because of human error and not our ability to produce food
-Social Darwinism = combining Malthus’ logic with Darwin and suggesting that giving money to poor people was immoral and against the natural order of things
-Adam Smith, founder of modern economics, suggested that a person following their own selfish interest was doing more for the greater good, and advocated for free trade as opposed to the tariffs in place at the time to protect domestic goods and workers
-David Ricardo expanded on Smith’s idea by introducing the idea of Comparative Advantage
-Friedrich Engels and Karl Marx looked at economic classes and explained that history could be explained by the conflict between workers and property owners → which would always eventually lead to workers revolting and issuing a classless and stateless system called communism
-End result vs Communism vs Free Market Capitalism
-Alfred Marshall published the Principles of Economics which embodied Classical Economics → organized concepts like supply & demand, marginal utility
-Keynes tried to explain why the Great Depression happened (while communism prospered) in his book A general Theory of Money, Interest, and Employment (which launched the field of Macroeconomics) → along with John Hicks they argued that Market Economics don’t self correct quickly because prices and wages take time to adjust → claimed that during recession monetary and fiscal policy was important to increase output and decrease unemployment
→ he didn’t support Communism but argued against classical economics that government intervention was bad → gave rise to Keynesian Economics
-Socialism = system where the means of producing and distributing goods is owned collectively or by a centralized government → allow for private property, and markets, but also have also have government ownership of industry, significant regulation, and big public programs like health care (Norway and Sweden love this)
-Austrian School of Economics = Friedrich Hayek and Ludwig Von Mises → argued that heavy state involvement never produces what it promises and that government intervention is a problem, because economics is too complicated to try to regulate
-This was backed by Milton Friedman in the USA, proposed deregulation (and said that Great Depression was a fault of monetary policy and not some inherent problem with capitalism) → Came to be called the Chicago School of Economics
-Building on Friedman’s idea, Monetarism → focused on price stability and money supply should be increased slowly and predictably to allow for steady growth
-At the same time Supply-Side Economics or Trickle-Down Economics → advocated deregulation, cutting taxes (especially corporate taxes)
-New Neoclassical Synthesis = monetarism + keynesian economics

If you ever hear an economist say they know exactly when something will happen, immediately dismiss them. Of course economists can't predict the future to exactly when something will happen. That is absurd and irrelevant. The part we should be focusing on is which economic ideology most accurately predicts certain types of results. Not when these results will occur. As an analogy. The classical example I've always hears is A sells 5 units to B, B sells 5 units to C and C sells 5 units to A. A then for whatever reason forecasts a bear market, and decides to hold onto some of his assets. A then only sells 4 units to B, B can then only produce and sell 4 units, etc, etc. A creates a self-fulfilling prophesy, and sells less units next time, and the cycle goes on.

The problem with this is that there is nothing stopping a new contender from benefiting from the price raises that a stable demand and a lower supply create. That is, unless there is a State around to back up a barrier to entry such as licensing, or even a State backed monopoly. (Think pharmaceuticals or telecommunications.)

The Keynesian solutions seems to by nature require government to gold excess value in reserve, or use inflation as a way to rapidly acquire value in order to spend strategically.

I don't know about you, but I have a serious problem seeing the reserve option being practical. Not only because the value in reserve is just as susceptible to market failures as everyone else's money is, but also that States seem pretty much incapable of not spending money they have. Plus, slowly pulling money into that reserve is in itself going to put a strain on the market because government doesn't produce value, they only take it. (Sometimes by purposeful artificial inflation.)

The other option doesn't seem that great either. Inflation is a tax you don't have to vote for. When you inflate a currency to gain value, you're really just siphoning off value into your new currency from the pool of the old currency. You actually lose value, too, because of the cost of physical currency production, and the levels of bureaucracy that the money has to be funneled through in order to be spent.

I'm a software engineer. I spend a lot of my time writing things called neural networks which are basic "brains" which learn based on input over time. Some applications of neural networks are search engines, advertisement placement, and stock trading. One thing I notice about these AIs is that they perform very well within their programmed data-set, but always seem to perform less well than projected. The reason for this is that we're human, and can only identify so many variables to use as input to the AI. Keynesian spending is no different. Even though the market may not produce what you're expecting, it will always produce the optimal result based on what it was given. Even in the case of Keynesian spending, you're only manipulating the market so far as you can understand it's "algorithm" and you yourselves said that economics is not an exact science.

Supposing that you had a perfect reserve without these adverse affects, when you spend specifically you produce artificial demand that you will have to continue maintaining forever. It's a band-aid you can't take off. You're just delaying the inevitable failure, and making it worse by siphoning money stolen from other markets to sustain your chosen market.

Main outtakes from the lesson:
1. In 1798, Thomas Malthus argued that population growth will outpace food production leading to starvation and death. This idea combined with the idea of Charles Darwin led to "Social Darwinism".

2. In 1776, Adam Smith published "Wealth Of The Nation" where he advocated Free Trade. David Ricardo later proposed "The Theory Of Comparative Advantage"- When both focus on what thy're best at, everyone benefits.

3. 1848 saw the birth of the Communist Manifesto by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels which look at economic clashes as conflict between workers and property owners.

4. 1890, Marshall embodied "Classical Economics" with a book 'principle Of Economics".

5. John Maynard Keynes launched the field of macroeconomics after the great recession. They claimed that during recessions ,it is necessary for government to get involved using monetary and fiscal policy too increase output and decrease unemployment. He challenged the classical economist who saw government intervention harmful for the economy.

6. Austrian School Of Economics: by Friedrich Hayek And Ludwig Vonmises argued heavy state involvement has never produced results and regulations were problems. They rejected all form of monetary and fiscal policies.

7. In that same vein, Milton Friedman and the Chicago School Of Economics advocated privatization of many functions which were assumed by the government.

8. Monetarism: It focused on price stability and argued money supply should be increased slowly and predictably to allow steady growth.

9. Supply Side Economics A.K.A Trickle Down Economics advocates deregulation and cutting down taxes especially corporate taxes.

10. Modern economics takes idea from classical economics including Keynesian and monetarism. This unified theory is called the Neo-Classical Synthesis

Yah, I'm definitely supportive of the Austrian and Chicago schools of economics. Politically, I'm a Minarchist Libertarian. I believe the only legitimate role of government is to protect people's rights to their own person/property and to punish those who infringe on these rights of others These rights include infringements on individuals' person/property such as murder, rape, theft, and fraud. The government protects against such infringements through law enforcement, a justice system, and a military. Everything else should be left to the people to decide for themselves. I do support lower taxes, but only after we get a few things taken care of. 1) Eliminate all illegitimate roles of government (everything except federal law enforcement, justice system, and military) which temporarily keeping taxes constant. 2) Use that additional tax revenue to pay off the national debt. 3) Then, eliminate all federal taxes and replace them with a single flat consumption tax that has one of the least negative impacts on economic growth of any tax, is fair to all, and also has exemptions on certain staple food items so as to not disadvantage the poor. Let me show what I mean with the numbers: The national debt is about $20 trillion. The 2015 budget had a total revenue of $3.8 trillion ($583 billion of which was borrowing). By far the largest of those three legitimate roles of government is military spending at $598 billion. Including the other two roles, let's say total legitimate expenditures amount to $700 billion. That leaves $2.517 trillion/year to pay off the national debt ($3.8 trillion minus $700 billion in legitimate spending minus $583 billion in additional borrowing; no more adding to the debt). $20 trillion divided by $2.517 trillion means we would have the debt paid off in 7.95 years (about 2 presidential terms). Once we eliminated all illegitimate spending and the national debt, now would cut all federal taxes. They would be replaced with a single flat consumption tax. Americans spend about $10.7 trillion per year. The government would need to raise $700 billion. Also, we must account for those exemptions on staple food items. Let's say that reduces taxable spending to $8 trillion. $700 billion divided by $8 trillion means there would only be a single tax rate of 8.75% for everyone. However, this can be further reduced through making those few legitimate roles more efficient and effective. To start, I don't believe the military should be involved in any nation that we are currently not at war with. That makes the over $150 billion we spend on foreign military bases illegitimate. That reduces the total government spending from $700 billion down to $550 billion. That reduces that tax rate to 6.88% ($550 billion divided by $8 trillion). Also, though I am skeptical about these legitimate roles being privatized, I am open to trying. I don't believe they are sufficient, but we do already have private armies, security services, and courts. As for state governments, I would want them to follow the same model, but I would definitely not want the federal government to enforce it.

Your concluding statement about not knowing the future and economic systems being too complex is one of the main arguments for the Austrian school, who (aside from private property rights) differentiate themselves from other schools in that they believe in the subjective theory of value. Where Keynes would say that the state (or money-printing agency) creates value, and Marx would say that labor creates value, Austrians would say that value is too complex and unpredictable to predict, and any monetary policies claiming to predict such things are false and, at times, unethical.

There are many who say you just need to separate "morality" from economic discussions and go with what appears to work.  The problem is that you can't separate morality from economics.  (Smith was a moral philosopher.)  Whenever you make an exchange with someone, there is an element of trust. This is magnified when you leave the barter economy and exchange a good/service for a little piece of paper with numbers on it.  Those pieces of paper represent promises/claims for other goods/services.  So trust is now key.  At the point of an exchange, you have a meeting of minds about what is fair.  Now enter a third party (likely government) who shows up and tries to alter the the value of what was agreed to in that exchange (monetary policy or some other redistribution).  Likely this third party is using some economic theory to justify the intervention.  The parties involved in the exchange now have a change being made to the value of what they trusted was fair for them at the time of the exchange.  This intervention therefor erodes trust in future exchanges as people become uncertain what they are getting in exchanges.  The promises of paper begin to fail as currency.  This is clearly evident when a country experiences hyper-inflation due to increase in the money supply.  Large misallocations of resources evolve as people try to expediently pedal their broken promises.  Morality absolutely matters.

The assumptions behind Keynesian monetary policy seem to be contradicted by historical evidence. No centrally planned economy has demonstrated a consistent ability to predict future demand of goods. Central planning frequently leads to unnecessary production or shortages. This can have tragic consequences if the shortages are for essentials like food. When prices are set by the market, prices automatically adjust to changes in demand. The aggregate actions of individuals set prices more efficiently than central planners. However governments still believe they know what the price of money should be AKA interest rates. Cutting interest rates effectively cuts wages in real terms and reduces the value of savings. This incentivises spending and can increase economic activity in the short term. However deficit spending and currency devaluation are not without consequences. In the long term, Keynesian manipulation as currently practiced is unsustainable because it allows postponement of fundamental economic problems. Since the root causes are not being address they continue to grow like a cancer. It would be better to undergo painful surgery now before the wounds become terminal.

It would be awesome if you guys devoted a whole episode to the ideas of Smith! I'm currently working on a paper which argues that Smith never argued for unconditional deregulation. A direct quote from the Wealth of nations is: “it is the proper business of law… to support” natural liberty (UChicago Press page 344; vol 1 bk 2 ch 3; in my copy it's about 6-7 pages from the end of the chapter "Money"). He wanted perfect liberty, not unconditional free markets. The confusion arises from the fact that in his day, the overwhelming majority of the barriers to perfect liberty were regulations that kept the market from being the most efficient, so he is almost always arguing for less regulations. But he says (to paraphrase) "this regulation is bad and this is why perfect liberty is better" and "that regulation is bad and this is why perfect liberty is better"; he never says "all regulations are bad and this is why perfect freedom is better." He just never does.
Admittedly the distinction btw perfect liberty and perfect freedom and natural liberty are extremely murky, possibly because when he was writing he saw no need to make such a distinction. Clearly my paper is a bit of a work in progress.

Social Darwinism isn't inherently wrong, its only wrong when taken to horrible extremes. The idea that we should strive to create a stronger gene pool and ensure that those with stronger traits produce offspring, is not particularly controversial last I checked. People generally don't engage in incest much anymore, and people who know they have a high chance of passing on genetic disorders sometimes choose not to reproduce. These are behaviors aimed at improving the human gene pool through survival of the fittest, are they not?

A lot of people seem to think that social Darwinism means deciding people who you view as inferior deserve a lower place in society, which is a form of racism. It certainly can mean that, but this is just an extreme idea about human natural selection, is it not? The idea isn't that some people deserve to die, its more that some people shouldn't be born, and those who may produce such offspring should avoid reproducing or do so via a sperm donor.

The problem is when you develop a whole framework of racial pseudoscience and decide that people who you already didn't like are naturally inferior to you and need to be killed off and stolen from to save the human race, or you forcibly prevent people with bad genetics from reproducing rather than letting natural selection run its course.

The idea that trying to improve the human genepool, or not reproducing when you think you'll detract from it, is a moral thing to do is a common and acceptable belief. The problem is when you derive from this idea that it's also okay to "improve" the human race by murdering those whom you view as inferior. Lobotomies=bad. Hitler=very bad. Going on the pill when you discover your potential child has a near 100% certainty of a horrible genetic condition=not bad, arguably even moral.

The big shift of monetarism was the shift regarding what tools to treat a recession with first. it's pretty contentious how distinct communism and socialism actually are but imho they can be understood to be distinct economic paradigms iff we are absolutely certain that historical materialism is the real deal

short and simple version of historical materialism defines an economic model relationally - how a given society accesses resources and how it generates classes more-or-less naturally based on that mode of access. Conflict naturally exists between classes since some always have more power than others and that conflict played out over time forces the mode of access to become more efficient and eventually the model and the classes to change as a result. Prime example, the shift from feudal agrarian societies built on landownership to industrial capitalist societies built on ownership of industry. Fully rendered it's a lot more nuanced but the crude example will do for the basics.

Socialists (who aren't usually distinct from communists unless you're talking about social democrats which we're not) generally assert that capitalism is not the end state of the process of the economic evolution of society, and believe that the tension which exists between the working class which produces wealth and the capitalist class which owns all the industry which is used to produce it will play out along improvements in the efficiency of industry to eventually reach a point where the working class will be able to organise and operate the economy independently of the capitalist class, seizing control of the economy and holding it in common, which is how socialism is defined. Communism is sometimes defined as distinct from socialism as a further mode of economics where ownership is conceptually abolished entirely, which would follow from socialism. That's still fairly contentious though. It doesn't easily gel with neoclassical economic theory.

What's important to keep in mind is that the common ownership of the economy rarely means state ownership of the economy and is where CCE keeps making an error. The state is thought by some socialists (not all out even necessarily a majority) to be instrumental to protecting the economy's progress towards socialism. Notably the communist revolutions of the world were led by parties which sought to use the state to rapidly industrialise the economy and forcibly collectivise some parts of it while nationalising others. Full collectivisation being the actual stated objective. At some point some communist parties (criticised by others for "revisionism" and generally being nuts) decided that nationalisation literarily was socialism - which would imply some sort of spiritual supremacy of the state as the literal embodiment of the will of the people, which is a joke if I ever heard one.

Welfare, regulation, and union enablement are justified by socialists as tools for improving the ability of the working class to advance itself, but are only really thought of as actually socialist economically by liberals and people who like Stalin a lot. They advance the end of socialism, but don't really actually represent its achievement, in that view.

Karl Marx despised socialism because it only institutionalized low wages subsidized by the bourgeois. He was worried about how it is when work gets more specialized, the job becomes less valuable, so the value of a person's life decreases. a person making a chair by hand is more valuable than someone using power tools to make a chair, which is more valuable than someone selling a chair at a target while the manufacturing line makes the chair.. The job becomes less and less valuable, and so do the lives of the people working these jobs. Wages get pushed down the more specialized work becomes. And while we create an abundance of stuff we both need and don't need, It would be better not to work and have the factories (or robots) work for us - especially in the future. This problem is definitely here in America, but we don't notice it as much, because we have outsourced as much cheap labor as possible. We have shifted a lot of this burden to other countries, but this burden of specialized,  low skill, low wage jobs still haunt us. These are the people who can't save money, become dependent on the government, and live lives with less value.

Why no mention of the Georgist school? Sure, it can be considered merely a radical strain of Classical Liberalism, but it stands out by emphasizing that property in Land (i.e., Natural Resources) is not justified like property in the fruits of labor. Taxing production or trade has very negative effects and morally can be considered the same as theft, but a government which taxes the rent of land actually strengthens the economy while doing nothing less ethical than any private landlord. A Georgist state collecting the rent is much more moral than a private party doing so if they used the funds to provide public goods or a citizens' dividend for the dispossessed.

Even though we can't predict the future, we can make some very reasonable assumptions. For example, it is almost certain that in a distant enough future, machines will perform almost any job and human will be unnecessary, not just for physical work but for intellectual as well. We can also reasonable assume that future machines will be able to improve themselves and get ever better at improving themselves the smarter they become.

The two assumptions above add to a very interesting view of the future. If free market economics remain viable as we approach that time, it can be shown that, whoever has a starting advantage (i.e. holds the first or best post-Singularity AI) will asymptotically control 100% of all markets. Present day company would like to swallow all of the world, but fail because the humans running it have limited time and intellect. This limitation will be removed and successful companies will keep swallowing smaller ones until there is nothing left. Even in a stalemate, even the slightest difference would eventually grow enough (remember, machines improve themselves based on the resources they have available) until a takeover becomes possible. Eventually, 100% of the economy will be owned by one single organisation.

Imagine a world where you own nothing and you are needed for nothing. Humans will be completely at the mercy of a single organisation. But you could make so that this one organisation works for everyone. Ironically, communism, the biggest economic failure of recent history, seems to be the system that is best prepared for the future.

Here is my 2 cents: The best economic system so far seems to be a regulated capitalist system with dashes of socialism. Two main categories of industry/services should be socialized, because profit should not be a concern: Education (K-college) and life-saving services (police, firefighters, healthcare); everything else should be capitalist, though it should also have reasonable regulation as well. By reasonable regulation I mean things like health codes, safety standards, environment codes, etc. Some often say that those regulations are cumbersome or unnecessary (because corporations will do these things on their own), but then I must point to what happened in this country before these regulations were in place, as well as to other countries nowadays that do not have such regulations, and the problems that they face because of that lack of regulation (workplace fires, chemical dumps, etc.). Also, pointing to the Great Depression/Recession as proof that we have too much regulation is problematic, mainly because the lack of regulation is what caused the problems in the first place (most recently, the repealing of Glass-Steagall). I also made a point of saying reasonable regulation, and pointed to specific examples, because I know that some regulations are indeed burdensome and unnecessary. I know that companies have influence over the government and lobby officials, and I am aware of concepts like "barriers of entry". I am not saying that every regulation is good, merely that a large number of them are vital, and that the idea of eliminating government's role in the private sector seems ludicrous to me. I am glad that we have health inspectors for food services, that factories are required to have fire-suppression systems, and that there are regulations about how you can dispose of hazardous chemicals and waste. That said, I also realize that these things do cost money, and that some corporations would rather open a factory in a country with cheaper standards, for instance. However, the solution to me seems to me to be that we should help raise the standards in other countries, not lower our standards to rival theirs. Take India, for instance: they have had numerous factories fires in last decade in the textile industry alone, as well as incidents of dumping dyes/chemicals into nearby rivers. The same happened here, before we regulated these industries (and it occasionally still happens, though companies are definitely incentive to have strict standards, rather than lax ones). I understand that we must remain competitive price-wise, but shouldn't we raise them to our standards, rather than lower our standards to meet theirs? That said, I do not mean to imply that we are the gold standard in terms of regulation; there are industries which are under-regulated in this country, such as mountain-top removal mining and hydraulic fracking, both of which have negative effects on the nearby environment and its inhabitants (both animals and property owners). We also under-regulate some of our more recent and risky financial tools/investments, such as mortgage-backed securities/derivatives. In short, lets not race to the bottom, lets race to the top, in terms of regulatory standards. Also, government should not run the show, but it has its place- protecting the citizens and their environment from the dangerous excesses of profit-seeking (though profit-seeking is a fine concept around which to build an economic system, at its worst extremes it can cause major damage, and the citizens need a referee to look after the public interest).
Malthus was not exactly wrong, merely inaccurate, from not having enough information at his disposal. Few economists are comprehensively wrong, some are simply more inaccurate than others.
